critique: This document pertains to the administration of government services during the early New Deal era. It defers the abolition of the Federal Coordinating Service, granting the President discretion to implement the change gradually. Given the context of the New Deal, this suggests a moderate level of government intervention in the economy. There is no information related to immigration, civil liberties, or social issues. The order does grant the President some flexibility in timing, which can be seen as a slight expansion of executive power, but it's primarily an administrative matter. The document does not explicitly address federalism, but the existence of a Federal Coordinating Service implies a degree of federal involvement. There is no clear ideological tilt.
